{{For|the [[Rascalz]] album|Cash Crop (album)}} [[File:Cotton By Hrushikesh Kulkarni.jpg|right|thumb|A [[cotton]] flower. Cotton is a significant cash crop. According to the National Cotton Council of America, in 2011, [[China]] was the world's largest cotton-producing country with an estimated 33,500,000 480-pound bales.<ref name="NCCOA">{{cite web | url=http://www.cotton.org/econ/cropinfo/cropdata/rankings.cfm | title=(Cotton) Production Ranking MY 2011 | publisher=[http://www.cotton.org National Cotton Council of America] | accessdate=April 3, 2012 | author=USDA-Foreign Agriculture Service}}</ref> India was ranked second at 26,500,000 480-pound bales.<ref name="NCCOA"/>]] {{multiple image | footer = [[Yerba mate]] (left, a key ingredient in the beverage [[Mate (beverage)|Mate]]), roasted [[coffee]] beans (middle) and [[tea]] (right) are all used for [[caffein]]ated infusions and have cash crop histories. | image1 = Mate mit Stengeln.jpg | width1 = 178 | alt1 = | caption1 = | image2 = Coffee Beans Photographed in Macro.jpg | width2 = 120 | alt2 = | caption2 = | image3 = Loose leaf darjeeling tea twinings.jpg | width3 = 125 | alt3 = | caption3 = }}
A '''cash crop''' is an [[Agriculture|agricultural]] [[crop]] which is grown for sale for profit. It is typically purchased by parties separate from a [[farm]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.epa.gov/agriculture/ag101/cropglossary.html | title=Ag 101: Crop Glossary | publisher=[http://www.epa.gov U.S. Environmental Protection Agency] | date=last updated: September 10, 2009 | accessdate=April 4, 2012}}</ref> The term cash crop is applied exclusively to the agricultural production of [[plant]]s; animal agriculture is not a part of the terminology. The term is used to differentiate marketed crops from [[Subsistence agriculture|subsistence crops]], which are those fed to the producer's own livestock or grown as food for the producer's family. In earlier times cash crops were usually only a small (but vital) part of a farm's total yield, while today, especially in the [[Developed country|developed countries]], almost all crops are mainly grown for revenue. In [[Least developed country|least developed countries]], cash crops are usually crops which attract demand in more developed nations, and hence have some export value.{{citation needed|date=April 2012}}
Prices for major cash crops are set in [[commodity market]]s with global scope, with some local variation (termed as "basis") based on [[Cargo|freight]] costs and local [[supply and demand]] balance. A consequence of this is that a nation, region, or individual producer relying on such a crop may suffer low prices should a [[bumper crop]] elsewhere lead to excess supply on the global markets. This system has been criticized by traditional farmers. [[Coffee]] is an example of a product that has been susceptible to significant commodity futures price variations.<ref name="CNN-Coffee">{{cite news | url=http://money.cnn.com/2010/09/10/markets/coffee_prices/index.htm | title=Coffee prices on the rise | publisher=[http://money.cnn.com CNN Money] | date=September 10, 2010 | accessdate=April 3, 2012 | author=Ellis, Blake}}</ref><ref name="Bloomberg-Coffee">{{cite news | url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-02-14/coffee-futures-fall-to-lowest-in-14-months-commodities-at-close.html | title=Coffee Futures Fall to Lowest in 14 Months: Commodities at Close | publisher=[http://www.bloomberg.com Bloomberg News] | date=February 14, 2012 | accessdate=April 3, 2012 | author=Galatola, Thomas}}</ref> __TOC__ {{-}}
==Globalization== Issues involving subsidies and trade barriers on such crops have become controversial in discussions of [[globalization]]. Many [[Developing country|developing countries]] take the position that the current international trade system is unfair because it has caused [[tariff]]s to be lowered in industrial goods while allowing for low tariffs and [[agricultural subsidies]] for agricultural goods.{{clarify|date=April 2012}} This makes it difficult for a developing nation to export its goods overseas, and forces developing nations to compete with imported goods which are exported from developed nations at artificially low prices. The practice of exporting at artificially low prices is known as [[Dumping (pricing policy)|dumping]],<ref name="bossche">{{cite book| last = Van den Bossche| first = Peter| year = 2005| title = The Law and Policy of the World Trade Organization| pages = 42| publisher = Cambridge University Press| location = Cambridge, UK| isbn= 978-0-511-12392-4| quote = Dumping, i.e. bringing a product onto the market of another country at a price less than the normal value of that product is condemned but not prohibited in WTO law.}}</ref> and is illegal in most nations. Controversy over this issue led to the collapse of the [[Canc√∫n]] trade talks in 2003, when the [[Group of 22]] refused to consider agenda items proposed by the [[European Union]] unless the issue of agricultural subsidies was addressed.
==Per climate zones== ===Arctic=== The [[Climate of the Arctic|Arctic climate]] is generally not conducive for the cultivation of cash crops. However, one potential cash crop for the [[Arctic]] is ''[[Rhodiola rosea]]'', a hardy plant used as a [[medicinal herb]] that grows in the Arctic.<ref name="Alaska Dispatch">{{cite web | url=http://www.alaskadispatch.com/article/medicinal-arctic-herb-alaskas-next-legal-cash-crop?page=full | title=Medicinal Arctic herb: Alaska's next (legal) cash crop? | publisher=[http://www.alaskadispatch.com/ Alaska Dispatch] | date=February 17, 2011 | accessdate=April 9, 2012}}</ref> There is currently consumer demand for the plant, but the available supply is less than the demand (as of 2011).<ref name="Alaska Dispatch"/>
===Temperate=== Cash crops grown in regions with a [[temperate climate]] include many cereals ([[wheat]], [[rye]], [[maize|corn]], [[barley]], [[oat]]s), oil-yielding crops (e.g. [[oilseed rape]]), vegetables (e.g. [[potato]]es), tree fruit or top fruit (e.g. [[apple]]s, [[cherry|cherries]]) and soft fruit (e.g. [[strawberry|strawberries]], [[raspberry|raspberries]]).
[[File:Cameron Highland Tea Plantation 2012.JPG|thumb|right|A [[tea]] plantation in the [[Cameron Highlands]] in [[Malaysia]]]]
===Subtropical=== In regions with a [[subtropical climate]], [[cereal|grain]] crops (e.g. [[rice]], [[millet]]), oil-yielding crops (e.g. [[soybean]]s) and some [[vegetable]]s and [[herb]]s are the predominant cash crops.
===Tropical=== In regions with a [[tropical climate]], [[coffee]],<ref name="CNN-Coffee"/> [[Cocoa bean|cocoa]], [[sugar cane]], [[banana]]s, [[Orange (fruit)|oranges]], [[cotton]] and [[jute]] (a soft, shiny [[Fiber crop|vegetable fiber]] that can be spun into coarse, strong threads), are common cash crops. The [[oil palm]] is a tropical palm tree, and the fruit from it is used to make [[palm oil]].<ref>{{Cite book|last1=Reeves |first1=James B. |last2=Weihrauch |first2=John L. |author3=Consumer and Food Economics Institute |title=Composition of foods: fats and oils |series=Agriculture handbook 8-4 |year=1979 |publisher=U.S. Dept. of Agriculture, Science and Education Administration |location=Washington, D.C. |oclc=5301713 |page=4}}</ref>
==By country== {{globalize|section|the Anglophone countries|date=June 2012}} ===Africa=== [[File:Jatropha curcas.jpg|thumb|left|''[[Jatropha curcas]]'' is a cash crop used to produce [[biofuel]].]] Around 60 percent of African workers are employed in the agricultural sector, with about three-fifths of African farmers being [[subsistence farming|subsistence farmers]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} For example, in [[Burkina Faso]] 85% of its residents (over two million people) are reliant upon cotton production for income, and over half of the country's population lives in poverty.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ncpa.org/pub/ba547 | title=Farm Subsidies: Devastating the World's Poor and the Environment | publisher=[http://www.ncpa.org/ National Center for Policy Analysis] | date=March 24, 2006 | accessdate=April 4, 2012 | author=Borders, Max Borders and Burnett, H. Sterling}}</ref> Larger farms tend to grow cash crops such as coffee,<ref name="CBBCNews">{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/newsid_4070000/newsid_4077200/4077204.stm | title=Guides: Poverty in Africa{{spaced ndash}} Growing cash crops | publisher=[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/ BBC] | date=June 9, 2005 | accessdate=April 4, 2012}}</ref> tea,<ref name="CBBCNews"/> cotton, cocoa, fruit<ref name="CBBCNews"/> and [[rubber]]. These farms, typically operated by large corporations, cover tens of square kilometres and employ large numbers of laborers. Subsistence farms provide a source of food and a relatively small income for families, but generally fail to produce enough to make re-investment possible.
The situation in which African nations export crops while a significant amount of people on the continent struggle with hunger has been blamed on developed countries, including the [[United States]],<ref name="NCPA">{{cite web | url=http://www.ncpa.org/pub/ba547 | title=Farm Subsidies: Devastating the World's Poor and the Environment | publisher=[http://www.ncpa.org National Center for Policy Analysis] | date=March 24, 2006 | accessdate=April 6, 2012 | author=Borders, Max and Burnett, H. Sterling}}</ref> [[Japan]] and the [[European Union]].{{citation needed|date=April 2012}} These countries protect their own agricultural sectors with high [[import tariff]]s and offer subsidies to their farmers,<ref name="NCPA"/> which some have contended as leading to the overproduction of commodities such as cotton,<ref name="NCPA"/> grain and milk.{{citation needed|date=April 2012}} The result of this is that the global price of such products is continually reduced until Africans are unable to compete in world markets,<ref name="NCPA"/> except in cash crops that do not grow easily in temperate climates.<ref name="NCPA"/>
Africa has realized significant growth in [[biofuel]] [[plantation]]s, many of which are on lands which were purchased by British companies.<ref name="Guardian-Biofuel">{{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/environment/2011/may/31/biofuel-plantations-africa-british-firms | title=Biofuels boom in Africa as British firms lead rush on land for plantations | publisher=[http://www.guardian.co.uk ''The Guardian''] | date=May 31, 2011 | accessdate=April 4, 2012 | author=Carrington, Damian and Valentino, Stefano}}</ref> ''[[Jatropha curcas]]'' is a cash crop grown for biofuel production in Africa.<ref name="Guardian-Biofuel"/><ref name="World Bank Study">{{cite web | url=http://www-wds.worldbank.org/external/default/WDSContentServer/IW3P/IB/2010/07/19/000158349_20100719162226/Rendered/PDF/WPS5364.pdf | title=Biofuels: Markets, Targets and Impacts | publisher=[http://www.worldbank.org The World Bank] | date=July 2010 | accessdate=April 6, 2012 | author=Timilsina, Govinda R. and Shrestha, Ashish}}</ref> Some have criticized the practice of raising non-food plants for export while Africa has problems with hunger and food shortages, and some studies have correlated the proliferation of land acquisitions, often for use to grow non-food cash crops with increasing hunger rates in Africa.<ref name="Guardian-Biofuel"/><ref name="World Bank Study"/><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/global-development/poverty-matters/2011/jan/28/africa-land-grabs-food-security | title=How land grabs in Africa could herald a new dystopian age of hunger | publisher=[http://www.guardian.co.uk ''The Guardian''] | date=January 28, 2011 | accessdate=April 6, 2012 | author=Bunting, Madeleine}}</ref> {{-}}
===Australia=== [[Australia]] produces significant amounts of [[lentil]]s.<ref name="ABC-Lentils">{{cite web | url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2010-02-26/humble-lentil-turns-into-cash-crop/344970 | title=Humble lentil turns into cash crop | publisher=[http://www.abc.net.au/ Australian Broadcasting Corporation] | date=February 28, 2010 | accessdate=April 4, 2012 | author=Staight, Kerry}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.abc.net.au/landline/stories/s99108.htm | title=Lentils offer farmers a better cash crop alternative | publisher=[http://www.abc.net.au/ Australian Broadcasting Corporation] (Landline) | date=February 13, 2000 | accessdate=April 4, 2012 | author=Courtney, Pip}}</ref> It was estimated in 2010 that Australia would produce approximately 143,000 tons of lentils.<ref name="ABC-Lentils"/> Most of Australia's lentil harvest is exported to the Indian subcontinent and the Middle East.<ref name="ABC-Lentils"/>
===New Zealand=== [[Kiwifruit]] is a significant cash crop in [[New Zealand]].
===United States=== {{Seealso|List of U.S. state foods}} [[File:OrangeBloss wb.jpg|thumb|Oranges are a significant U.S. cash crop]]
Cash cropping in the United States rose to prominence after the [[baby boomer]] generation and the end of World War II. It was seen as a way to feed the large population boom and continues to be the main factor in having an affordable food supply in the United States. According to the 1997 U.S. Census of Agriculture, 90% of the farms in the United States are still owned by families, with an additional 6% owned by a partnership.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.epa.gov/agriculture/ag101/demographics.html | title=Ag 101: Demographics | publisher=[http://www.epa.gov U.S. Environmental Protection Agency] | date=last updated: September 10, 2009 | accessdate=April 3, 2012}}</ref> Cash crop farmers have utilized precision agricultural technologies<ref>{{cite web | url=http://southeastfarmpress.com/equipment/alabama-growers-reap-big-savings-precision-ag | title=Alabama growers reap big savings with precision ag | publisher=[http://southeastfarmpress.com Southeast Farm Press] | date=February 2, 2011 | accessdate=April 3, 2012 | author=Creamer, Jamie}}</ref> combined with time-tested practices to produce affordable food. Based upon [[United States Department of Agriculture]] (USDA) statistics for 2010, states with the highest fruit production quantities are California, Florida and Washington.<ref name="AgStats-California">{{cite web | url=http://www.nass.usda.gov/Statistics_by_State/California/Publications/California_Ag_Statistics/2010cas-frt.pdf | title=Fruit and Nut Crops (California) | publisher=[http://www.nass.usda.gov/ USDA National Agriculture Statistics Service] | date=October 28, 2011 | accessdate=April 6, 2012}}</ref>

===Vietnam=== [[Coconut]] is a cash crop of [[Vietnam]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://vietnamnews.vnagency.com.vn/Economy/221019/coconut-growers-switch-crops.html | title=Coconut growers switch crops | publisher=[http://vietnamnews.vnagency.com.vn Viet Nam News] | date=February, 20 2012 | accessdate=April 7, 2012}}</ref>
==Global cash crops== Coconut palms are cultivated in more than 80 countries of the world, with a total production of 61 million tonnes per year.<ref>Food And Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. Economic And Social Department. Statistics Division. (September 2, 2010). [http://faostat.fao.org/site/567/DesktopDefault.aspx?PageID=567#ancor FAOSTAT ‚Äì Production ‚Äì Crops <nowiki>[Selected annual data]</nowiki>]. Retrieved April 14, 2011 from the FAOSTAT Database.</ref> The [[coconut oil|oil]] and [[coconut milk|milk]] derived from it are commonly used in cooking and frying; coconut oil is also widely used in [[soap]]s and [[cosmetics]].
==Black market cash crops== [[File:Acapulco-gold.jpg|thumb|In the U.S., [[Cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] has been termed as a cash crop.<ref name="ABCNews-Cannabis"/>]] [[Coca]], [[Opium poppy|opium poppies]] and [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] are significant [[black market]] cash crops, the prevalence of which varies. In the United States, cannabis is considered by some to be the most valuable cash crop.<ref name="ABCNews-Cannabis">{{cite web | url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/story?id=2735017&page=1 | title=Marijuana Called Top U.S. Cash Crop | publisher=[http://abcnews.go.com ABC News] | date=December 18, 2006 | accessdate=April 3, 2012 | author=Venkataraman, Nitya}}</ref> In 2006, it was reported in a study by Jon Gettman, a marijuana policy researcher, that in contrast to government figures for legal crops such as corn and wheat and using the study's projections for U.S. cannabis production at that time, cannabis was cited as "the top cash crop in 12 states and among the top three cash crops in 30."<ref name="ABCNews-Cannabis"/> The study also estimated cannabis production at the time (in 2006) to be valued at $35.8 billion USD, which exceeded the combined value of corn at $23.3 billion and wheat at $7.5 billion.<ref name="ABCNews-Cannabis"/>
